document_title: Food poisoning: Causes, symptoms and treatment instructions
subsection_content:
Common causes of food poisoning include:
Salmonella bacteria (bacteria that causes typhoid) cause symptoms of nausea, headache, dizziness, fever and diarrhea.; Staphylococcus toxins found in milk and undercooked poultry cause dizziness, nausea, headaches, rapid pulse, and diarrhea.; The bacterial toxin Clostridium botulinum in spoiled and rancid fish meat destroys the central nervous system and medulla, causing death.; Aflatoxin fungal toxin on nuts such as peanuts, soybeans, sunflower, cashew, and corn; powders from these seeds when moldy.; Hepatitis A viruses (HAV) and Norwalk in foods such as raw vegetables and cold prepared foods; molluscs such as oysters, snails, and mussels that live in dirty water; Small liver fluke in dishes made from raw fish salad, grilled fish, unboiled snails.; Heavy metals such as arsenic, lead, mercury, selenium mixed in food.; Residues of pesticides; Food additives and preservatives are not allowed to be used, or are used in excessive doses or expired, etc.
See more: Mushroom poisoning: Symptoms, causes, diagnosis and treatment.
Clostridium botulinum bacteria is the cause of Minh Chay pate poisoning
